The Large Fish Index (LFI) was developed to respond to fishing pressure on the proportion of large fish in demersal fish communities (species living on or near the seafloor) (Rochet et al., 2010). Time series dating back to the 1920s have shown depletion of the proportion of large fish occurred during the 1980s and 1990s in the North Sea (Greenstreet et al., 2011) and Firth of Clyde (Heath and Spiers 2014).

Background Fishing mortality constrains the age structure of fish communities, reducing the proportion of larger and older individuals of species impacted.

The Large Fish Index (LFI) was developed to respond to fishing pressure on the proportion of large fish in demersal fish communities (species living on or near the seafloor) (Rochet et al., 2010). Time series dating back to the 1920s have shown depletion of the proportion of large fish occurred during the 1980s and 1990s in the North Sea (Greenstreet et al., 2011) and Firth of Clyde (Heath and Spiers 2014).

u_shaped_ranking.context_window: Assessment Method Indicator Metric and Data Collection The Large Fish Index (LFI) was developed for the North Sea (Greenstreet et al., 2011, 2012), and uses estimates of fish biomass density-at-length provided by trawl surveys. The LFI indicator methodology was first applied in the North Sea (Greenstreet et al., 2011) and has subsequently been adapted to expand the indicator to the Celtic Seas (Shephard et al., 2011), Bay of Biscay and Iberian Coast (Modica et al., 2014) and Wider Atlantic (Mindel et al., 2018).
